This is called a moire.  It occurs when a screen or a screened image (printed) is viewed through another screen. You use to see it in TV shows where there were venetian blinds...a moving pattern would emerge.  Its impossible to focus on and will make you queasy.  Just something i learned as a color tech in the printing industry.

every video I've ever watched is one massive optical illusion... there is zero motion happening... ever! It is a series of static images that change quickly enough to appear to be moving... but in fact they are not. This is true for any frame rate we want to choose... it is simply a series of still images strung together at a fast enough speed to fool our brains into thinking we are seeing actual motion.

I don’t think the kid in the road illusion is a good idea.  Sure, it’s good in theory, but not in practice.  A car seeing ‘a kid in the road’ would likely slam on the brakes, not just slow down, which could lead to an accident if a car behind them is following too close or not paying attention.  The driver could also swerve to left, into oncoming traffic, and possibly collide into an oncoming car or lose control of their vehicle.  Also, if it does cause someone to slow down, it only works the first time.  The person will learn that it’s fake the first time and if they use that road in future they can travel at whatever speed they want.  Just use speed bumps.

The illusion of control can also be seen in elevator "close door'" buttons. All elevators have them and none of them work. The illusion of control is akin to walking on a frozen lake. You take a few steps, and the ice holds. It must be fine then to take a few more, but the ice breaks, and you are suddenly in the freezing water. Your overconfidence has lead you to walk too far, and you realize too late just how thin the ice really was.

This video, as more of Vsauce videos, starts with a certain subject and then shift slowly to something completely different. In its path it assumes more and more by combining facts while  leaving out other facts which are not handy to make the point. Like always at the 'end conclusion' I always feel tricked into a direction and it takes a minute to make the perspective normal again. Vsauce is an incredible smooth talker but that does mean he is automatically right. The videos lack multiple perspective critical views, open ends en sticking to the subject to make a point. The sidesteps or intro path might be considered false science or putting up a smoke screen to off-set the not really smart people like myself. Michael, a tip for you: As you may know, with few exceptions, when the letter C is followed by an e, i, or y, it represents the "soft C" sound (like an /s/ sound)--as in cell, city, or cycle. So when there is a double "c" in an English word, and the second C is followed by e, i, or y, the first C usually represents the "hard C" sound (like the sound of K), and the second represents the soft C (s).
This pattern is found in words like accident and accent. It is also, in case you haven't guessed by now, found in succinct. "Suck-sinked."

I saw a thermal inversion back around '84. It was in the 3rd week in Dec. That whole week, the days were in the low 80's setting records. The day I saw this was a record high of 85, but there was a cold front pushing down wirt arctic air, that brought a record low, for that date. of 13. the cold air was moving in at a clipper rate with sustained winds around 40 mph and gust up to 70 mph. About 25 miles.

South of Montgomery, there is a tall tower (1933 feet high) that is the TV tower for WSFA in Montgomery. It is lit up with huge flashing strobes that are bright enough to look like lightning. I was heading home from Birmingham that night around 3 am. about an half an hour after the front started pushing through Montgomery. I was 15 or so miles north of the city, when I had started seeing a flashing speck that looked like it was just floating over the city. After a few minutes I realized that I was seeing that tower. It looked like a repeating lightning volt flashing above Montgomery.

I was amazed to see it from where I was. The only thing it could have been was a thermal inversion cause by the rapid advance of that arctic air pushing through the south. There was a 62 degree temperature difference. It is one truly amazing "natural" illusion that I've ever seen!

What about making decisions, which will affect your future? You can imagine what could happen and it would be just your imagination. But also other people's experiences don't help because it's uncertain whether the same thing, which happened to them, will also happen to you (there are different circumstances since it's another person). And given that you can't control your future, what should you do? :D Maybe such decisions are a mix of these all - you imagine the wanted outcome, kinda reassure yourself with other people's opinions that it's really the right thing to do and then blindly believe that you are capable of achieving it. Yet there's no proof that exactly this imaginatory situation will happen and, according to you, it actually won't!

Okay, okay... Let's just say that what we imagined won't be exactly the same, but still very close to it. The advices shouldn't be completely off. And that we can at least partly control our future by making these huge decisions, which will for sure affect it.

Conditions under which it's difficult to calculate and factor in movements don't only include eye movements but those of the entire body. Out hiking you often need to stop moving yourself in order to check if that dot outlined on the far mountain ridge is alive and mobile or just a piece of rock. A dog approaching you on the trail will stop for the same reason, but closer on account of its relatively poor sight. A particularly dramatic motion effect occurs when you're passing an airport and an incoming or outgoing plane that must be doing a lot of kph appears to be hanging stationary in the air. Must be because observer and plane motions cancel against a common reference point. That would explain UFOs which apparently hover and then suddenly dart off - they're just that already moving plane subsequently changing course relative to the observer.

Pigeons are reported to see the exact reverse of the illusion whereby objects appear smaller when enclosed by larger areas, (a version of which is known as the Ebbinghaus). My theory: pigeons experience perspective in reverse to us, far off objects need to look bigger than nearby ones. So they couldn't see down the inside walls of a tunnel the way we can, but they could look "down" the whole outside surface of a tube at once from the same angle. Could be useful.

Illusion does NOT mean 'to have fun'. It means an act of deception or something of deceptive appearance, and has meant so since the at least 1400. Even it's Latin roots, which I looked up to be sure, was something like 'to play' or 'to play with, mockingly'. Not quite the same thing, and even taking the similarity of meaning from so long ago is as silly as saying that 'bead' sill means 'prayer', or even suggesting that 'dumb' is still a common and legitimate term for those who can't physically speak.

VSauce, I love your videos, but if you could stop using etymological fallacies, it would stop driving your linguist fans nuts. Instead of saying "The word 'illusion' means...," you could say "The word 'illusion' once meant" or "The word 'illusion' derives from a word for X." In Modern English, the word "illusion" does not in fact mean "fun," just as "decimate" does not in fact mean to reduce by a tenth, "terrific" does not mean frightening, and so on. "Etymological fallacy" has its own wikipedia page if you want a quick run-down of why saying things like "Literally. Illusion means fun" is not logically sound.

About the Titanic: As a side note (I went to the Titanic museum in Tennessee), the Titanic was sinking and shot off fireworks, but the captain of the Californian saw that the fireworks were not the color of distress flares and so moved on. The Titanic could have sunk because of the brittleness of the metal making up its sides (it could have had too much silicon). Thus, while the Titanic may very well have been able to hit the iceberg head on and survive, the iceberg scraped against the sides of the ship, which cracked and caused her demise. I'm not 100% sure on all of this, but I'm fairly certain; I'd be happy if some folks could verify this.

Here is a question that I came up with and has been really messing with my mind.


Theoretically, if you could freeze time, you could live for an infinite amount of time without any outside viewers noticing a single second. If you brought a friend with you into "frozen time" and killed him, what would happen to his matter? Normally, when you die, you decompose over a few years and eventually get "recycled" back into the ecosystem. If someone died in "frozen time" they would decompose for an infinite amount of years. The matter would sit there, literally, forever. What would happen to their matter? Would it break the laws of physics and disappear from existence altogether? 

Just a question that has been mind-boggling to me since I thought of it.

Hey, Vsauce:

When i had to undergo 8 treatments of "ECT," around the time after i completed my third treatment, for some reason i always knew what would happen next, and I could change the outcome of events. With very, in depth detail, as well. Same thing happened to one other guy there that was about to refuse emergency ECT, and i told him how its changed me into a much more optimistic person, and i changed his mind. After his 4th treatment, he asked me "Is it bad that I'm knowing what will happen next? Can the ECT be doing something bad to me, or maybe psychological?" That's when i mentioned i was starting to have that same thing starting to happen. A few months later, those precognitive events gradually faded away, but still happens on rare occasions. So here is a suggestion: "Why does ECT work?" or maybe "What happens to somebody during ECT?" This is something that really peaks my curiosity, and it would be awesome if you could maybe make a video on something like this. (:

The End of History Illusion reminds me of an illusion I've noticed.

Whenever we learn something new, our new-found knowledge clouds our mind with the illusion that others know it as well. Everything we know appears to be common knowledge, and this makes it much harder for us to communicate and sympathize with people who don't know what we know.

The hardest part about learning something new, is remembering what it was like to not know.

The illusion of control is expressed more in brains able to perform faster, therefore make more calculations in a given period of time. Lets say 2 guys with 2 different speeds of data processing in their heads are given the same amount of information. The one with higher performance can come up with more combinations than the second one with lower speed of info analysis. Now, if all the test subjects had with almost the same amount of info regarding the stock markets in their heads and they were told the 3 buttons make the prices rise, stabilize and/or decrease, the one with faster brain can subconsciously calculate the possibility of a certain event in their heads faster and push the appropriate button not even thinking that it wasn't the button that changed the stock market prices but they actually pressed the button responsible for the event that was going to happen at that moment.

@Vsauce Hi Michael! In the picture at 00:27 there's a little error... the latin for "illusion" is not "illusionem" but "illusio"; "illusionem" is the accusative case of the noun "illusio" ( but you translated it as a verb ).
The verb is "illudere", a composition of  in + ludere, which paradigm is "illūdo, illūdis, illusi, illusum, illūdĕre"
sources: i have studied latin for 5 years at school

You missed the greatest illusion of all; free will. If we were to duplicate this universe a trillion times over, every choice we make in every one of them throughout our entire lives would be the same. This is because our consciousness is a product of a complex network of chemical reactions occurring within our brains. We are but matter and like all matter, we must abide by the laws of physics. There is only one possible outcome to every reaction, including the ones taking place within us. You posted a video a while back referring to an experiment in which people were wired up to machines and weren't instructed to do anything. The machines determined that the intent for the actions they did while waiting came nanoseconds after the actions themselves. Their free will was something their brains invented.

Religions, philosophies, teachers, your family, your mother, they all encourage you to control. We have never asked: Who is the controller?

The illusion of control thing reminds me of how in role playing games, or any games that involve dice, really, people who are really serious about it will sometimes have rituals surrounding the dice. "Rolling out" the low numbers, using a different die if you rolled poorly, blowing on the dice. That sort of thing. Even very non-superstitious people will have these rituals, and I've even felt myself developing superstitions like this. I guess it's because the stakes are so high, people feel like they need to do everything in their power to try and tilt the outcome in their favor. A die role is by it's nature random, but the human brain is hard wired to find patterns that might help them survive, so it overanalyzes it to the point where it finds patterns that aren't there.

I once took an intelligence/psychological test that required me to click buttons to make dollar amounts go up and down.  After not seeing a pattern, I decided that the buttons did nothing, and just kept clicking the last button over and over until the time ran out.  Later, I was told that I got the right answer, but not for the reason I thought.  Even though the numbers going up and down were random, the button I just started mashing just happened to be the one that was giving the highest payouts, and I didn't even notice.  So what would you call that?  Illusion of LACK of control?  It's also a bit unsettling that I "passed" a test by accident.
